title: About Ben Wards
text:
How I Got Here
I completed a masters at the university of Alberta and undergrad in math at the University of Calgary. I then partially completed a Phd (ABD) in Geophysics. Even though I’ll never complete my phd I learn’t a lot, writing, presentations, matlab, signal processing, and simulations of acoustic and anisotropic wave equations. I’m now on the road to learning python and data science.

title: Post With Code
text:
Plot Something with python
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(subplot_kw={"projection": "polar"})
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()




Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis

title: Keyboard Shortcuts for the Terminal and vscode on Linux
text:
A summary of linux commands that I use for coding in python. Try to learn one command every time you program.


There are many over lapping keyboard shortcuts between the terminal and vscode. I recommend learning the over lapping ones.



shortcut
description




Ctrl + a
goto beginning of line


Fnc + ←
goto beginning of line


Ctrl + e
goto end of line


Fnc + →
goto end of line


Ctrl + w
delete one word backwards


Ctrl + k
remove cursor to beginning of line


Ctrl + u
remove cursor to end of line


Ctrl + y
undone


Ctrl + Shift + c
copy to terminal


Ctrl + Shift + v
paste to terminal


Ctrl + F
move one forward











Shortcut
description




Ctrl+C
copy


Ctrl+v
paste


Ctrl+x
cut line


Ctrl+⬆
move view up


Ctrl+⬇
move view down


Alt+⬆
move line up


Alt+⬇
move line down


Fnc+⬆
move to top of page


Fnc+⬇
move to bottom of page


Ctrl+]
indent line


Ctrl+[
out dent line


Alt+Z
toggle word wrap


Ctrl+F
find


Ctrl+H
replace



You can define custom shortcuts but learn the default ones first. When you go to different computer you will have to reprogram the shortcuts.






Shortcut
description




Ctrl+P
quick open a file


Ctrl+Shift+A
toggle block command


Ctrl+Shift+P
show command palette


Fnc+F11
full screen


Ctrl+d
select word


Shift+Ctrl+→/←
select words left or right


Shift+Alt+→/←
smart select



PDF of keyboard shortcuts

title: Timeseries with Prophet
text:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

df = pd.read_csv("Hourly_Metered_Volumes_and_Pool_Price_and_AIL.csv")
df["Date"] = pd.to_datetime(df["Date_Begin_Local"])
df.set_index("Date", inplace=True)


# print(df.columns)

# df_daily_pool_avg = df.set_index("Date").resample('D').mean()


AIL_hourly_2021 = df[df.index.year == 2021]
AIL_hourly_2022 = df[df.index.year == 2022]


plt.plot(
    AIL_hourly_2021.index,
    AIL_hourly_2021.ACTUAL_AIL,
    label="2021",
)
plt.legend()
plt.show()
plt.plot(
    AIL_hourly_2022.index,
    AIL_hourly_2022.ACTUAL_AIL,
    label="2022",
)
plt.legend()




<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x7ff238329b10>






from prophet import Prophet
import logging
import warnings
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

train_data, test_data = train_test_split(AIL_hourly_2022, test_size=0.2, shuffle=False)

logging.getLogger("prophet").setLevel(logging.ERROR)
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

m = Prophet()

data = train_data
data["ds"] = train_data.index
data["y"] = train_data.ACTUAL_AIL

m.fit(data)

future_dates = m.make_future_dataframe(periods=1)
predictions = m.predict(future_dates)
predictions
plt.plot(future_dates, predictions.yhat)
plt.show()
m.plot_components(predictions)

title: Linux on Macbook Pro 2012
text:
I have two former windows machine that are running ubuntu just great. But the mac runs a little hot and the battery time is reduced.
Computer: 2012 mid 15inch MacBook pro

title: Linux on Macbook Pro 2012
section: What was wrong with MAC OS?
text:
What was wrong with MAC OS?

homebrew broke
hard to update
no support from mac
hard to build anything from source.
love apt, apt-get, installer, more familar with command line tools on linux.

title: Linux on Macbook Pro 2012
text:
Installation
I tried to install many different flavors, making probably 10 different bootable usb keys. The only way to get the wifi and gpu drivers to install was to use a flavor of Ubuntu.
I need a new hard drive so I thought should take the time to install Linux.

title: Linux on Macbook Pro 2012
text:
Extras for Ubuntu

install zsh
install oh-my-zsh
remap caps-lock to control
remap function key to Control
install anaconda (for data science and python)
install vscode
configure git/github
adjust to dark theme
change firefox to dark theme

title: Git commands and Configuration
text:
Initiating a git repository from a folder:
git init


Checking which file differs from current working director and the head:
git status
git rm --cached
Find the list of files in the index
git ls-files



List of commits
git log
List commits with oneline and in graph mode to see branches,
git log --graph --oneline
List of all recent git commits including amends and reverts
git reflog



View all exists branches
git branch
How to delete a branch
git branch -D <branch_to_delete>
git  rebase

title: Git commands and Configuration
section: SSH Keys and Passphrases with Github
text:
SSH Keys and Passphrases with Github

Generate a private public key pair

The public key in ~/.ssh is .pub file

Get that key to run with ssh
Upload the public key to github
Set the remote with ssh

ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "wardsbd@gmail.com"
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
The command line authenticates with ssh so you have to set the remote with ssh not https. Go to your github page like you were going to find the clone address and choose ssh to down load the correct link.
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:benwardswards/quartoalgoverse.github.io.git
Checking your credentials:
ssh -T git@github.com
Github docs for authentication
